comment: This class was remarkably stressful for no reason. The course material is very reasonable but the professor makes it hard. Midterm and final were 8-10 free response questions about anything in or related to the course, with no partial credit nor study guide, homework is loosely tied into lectures and grading is arbitrary.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I took him for a graduate class, I didn't have another choice. He sent emails earlier in the semester I felt were kind of rude. His homework are huge, start it early. The deadlines are 8AM. There is a semester long project. His tests are not easy, you will have to write pseudocode algorithms. Don't take him if you can. No point on him being so.
Did not provide proper resources but assignments and exams are on deep concepts which are nowhere to be seen in his lecture notes.

The class is not hard but his grading is strict. The the homework come straight from the book. The test are all short answer. The main problem is that if you do not answer in the way he wants you will lose points. Just a tough grader overall.

Had him for 3305L. Learned more in the lab than I did from the class (had with another professor). He gives his normal class a lot of work, but the labs are all standard. Doesn't help much when you ask questions; always tries to get you to figure it out. Seems to take points off randomly. Really nice guy and doesn't take off points for late labs.

I barely came out of this class with a C and Ive taken the class before so I had an idea of the material. There are assignments almost every week and if you take him for lab as well its the same. He was a good lecturer but the hw was difficult. Also there were 2 test and a final with no study guide so good luck trying to figure out what to study.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lots of homework

comment: He's smart and his lectures are okay, but it doesn't translate to the homework. It's notorious for being hard; doesn't matter if your code works, if it's not efficient enough don't expect a good grade. Tests are more conceptual though, so that gives some leverage. Unless you get your rocks off to reading about code, expect this course to be tough.

Seriously if you want to sleep at night then do not take this professor. His assignments are impossible and the tests are even worse. I get that we're supposed to be challenged but this class was too hard for a bunch of college kids. He also makes everything a joke so if you actually want to learn and get sleep at night please do yourself a favor.

Dr. Gayler is one of the most detail oriented, hardest, and fastest professors at KSU. He also cares about his students more than most do. If you plan on just showing up, doodling through lecture, and doing the homework the night before, don't bother. If you actually want to learn, take Gayler. And ask questions, he'll answer questions any time
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He assigns more work than any professor I've ever had, half of which is based on information he doesn't cover in the lectures, and he's notoriously unhelpful when asked for help. Also, he -and i quote- "doesn't believe in curving" and he has no problem with the fact that half his students fail his class.

TOUGH grader, class is all done through KSU web which is quite annoying cause you are unaware of all assignments and grades. Labs are incredibily counter productive. Design of this class is horrific. Prepare to use unnecessary methods. avoid him and patrick bobbie if possible. extra credit will be difficult and wont help much.

Gayler is a tough one. Expect his class to be difficult, but you should come out of it a better programmer for sure. If you think that Data Structures is going to be easy, you must not realize how crucial they are.   Do the homework anytime before the night its' due and you'll be fine. Definitely taking him again because of his overall knowledge.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Professor Gayler is a decent professor, but his faults lie in his assignments, tests, and grading. Every week, he gives his class an abysmal assignment and a challenging lab that are much harder than the material associated with it. His tests are mostly over conceptual stuff, with some coding, but be sure to study the concrete material just in case
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: He pretty much takes forever with anything - he takes weeks to grade your test and assignments and throughout that time there are more assignments while you haven't got back the previous. We got our second test back 2 days before the final! The tests are pretty hard and for 50 minutes of class, very long! I would suggest you avoid this professor.

Gayler definatey knows his stuff, and his humor is definately entertaining. You'll learn a lot, but he takes FOREVER to upload lab solutions.. That's my only issue with the class, and the book itself doesnt help that much.

It's pretty depressing that this is the best professor that KSU has to offer for this course. If you can tank through stressful weekly assignments, redundant and tedious labs, and migraine inducing tests, then by all means! Take this class! If you can't, then try to find an easier alternative. Emphasis on the "try."
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: This professor is one of the hardest I've ever took. Gayler does not slow down, if you're behind you won't catch up because there will be a new topic every week with 1/2 assignments + lab on top of it. The assignments are hard and almost impossible to get A or even B+. Please take someone else if you can, don't do this to yourself!!

Every week, he gives his students some excruciatingly tedious homework with vague grading requirements which unfortunately counts for most of your overall grade. His tests are not too bad, but be sure to study hard for them - given that he doesn't give you another assignment in the same week. Regardless, his class is hard - too hard for some.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Avoid his professor at all costs if you value your sanity and your GPA. He's an extremely tough grader with vague grading requirements. He will at times arbitrarily take points away for the smallest reasons, nullifying your efforts for an assignment. Don't take this professor! Find an easier alternative!

The hardest class I have ever taken, heavy assignments every week. You think you got your program working and figured out, expecting an A? You are mistaking, he will send you back your assignment 5 days later, with grade of C. Really tough grader. Do not take him unless you REALLY need to. Teaches out of the book, has only experience from school...

Dr. Gayler is the toughest teacher and hardest grader I've ever had. He's not specific with what he wants, teaches only in abstract concepts and not real concrete topics, and expects you to be able to do assignments covering concrete things after only touching on the abstract. Mandatory attendance and hard, long tests. DO NOT turn in things late.

Data structures is naturally hard but he's your best choice. Gaylor knows the class better than any other professor and gives better explanations of what you need to do on the assignment. The hardest parts about Gaylor are his sense of humor (it's very cringe) and the test because no one ever knows exactly what to study (same for other profs tho).

It is a hybrid class where you have to watch the lecture before class. During class you pretty much work on you lab the whole time. He is very hard at grading, you either do really well, or really poor. Homework is a must to pass the class. If your code does not run, you get a 0.
Hard teacher, tough grader. Also a very boring class. Would not recommend and there are better CS 1301 teachers in the school.

Don't be fooled by his reviews for programming principles classes. At least for 3401, he expects you to know java like the back of your hand. Spends no time at all going over code or explaining new coding concepts. MAKE SURE you fully understand java before taking this class. He is a very harsh grader (basically either 0 or 100).

I took CS2301 as a Freshman which was my mistake. This class is a lot of hard work. Professor Gayler was always there to try to help me. He was always telling our class that it was to quiet and that we werent asking enough questions. The lectures are all recorded and they are long and boring. The homework takes a long time and it is a must.

Gayler is a really smart guy. The way he teaches is pretty clear cut and to the point. He'd give some (not-so-funny) jokes with his program examples and that tends to help a lot. He also records the lectures. Attendance is a must. There's only 2 exams, which aren't too bad. Study. Do the hw and you'll be fine. He's always in his office too.

Worst teacher I have ever had in my life. IF YOU HAVE NO KNOWLEDGE OF C RUN AS FAR AS POSSIBLE. Uses onenote to draw a picture of what we are going to do but it is always jumbled up. Everything we talk about is a somehow finds it way back to talking bad about Athens and UGA. Starts the class with terrible jokes but thats a lot of teachers here.

Difficult class but great professor. This is my fourth class with Gayler and I have enjoyed each class. He is an instructor who teaches well and answers questions (the ones that you ACTUALLY ask). Very helpful. His assignments are medium difficulty but his tests require a great amount of understanding the material.
Dr. Gayler is all about thoroughness. He explains everything in extreme detail, and provides fantastic examples. Would recommend!

Hard class, Great professor. The material covered in the course is a lot, and the Test are very difficult. Do well on the Assignments and the 3 projects, ask questions when you are confused. He will go over something if you do not understand.... Great professor but be warned late nights will be weekly.

Great professor. He's very knowledgable about these various subjects taught in class. Easy to understand and very helpful when you have questions. The semester-long programming project is not too difficult just DO NOT PROCRASTINATE. Not a lot of book use but you will have several small assignments on a question or two out of the textbook.

Gayler is very good at making the concepts of this course extremely clear. While the course-long project takes effort, it's purpose is to help you engage in the concepts of the class. His tests are the most difficult part, but it's not difficult to excel in this class. Attendance is not mandatory, but recommended.

Very accessible (he's even available on Google chat). Tests are essay, very hard, and cover lots of material. The real meat of this course is the project that spans the entire semester. You will have to write an interpreter in three languages (Java, Ada, & Python). Unless you're a coding wizard this is not a weekend project. It will take you weeks.

He is willing to help and answer questions. Weekly homework assignments are tough. Tests are essays and final is cumulative. He gave an opportunity for extra credit on the midterm. I wish he would do more examples related to the homework. He insists on using Ada, a programming language that is almost impossible to find info about on the internet.

Great teacher! His lectures always come with in-class examples that really let you grasp the material, and the assignments are always relevant to what was discussed in class. Tests are challenging, but by no means should you let that scare you. Dr. Gayler is smart, funny, and extremely friendly. I would recommend this professor to everyone!

Very informative class. Could live without the constant jokes on UGA, but outside of that the lectures are good. He records them with camtasia and the files are difficult to manage and fairly unwieldy in size. This man wants you to succeed and is always offering and giving help. A true professor.

Took during summer. He tried to pack 16 weeks into 8 and was not willing to let anything go. 3 exams PLUS a comprehensive final AND a group project on top of homework every week. He is unbending on grades. If you have an 89.9, you just got yourself a B. No grading curve either. He does try to help those who ask- that's the only good thing I can say

Amazing teacher. The class was quite difficult and the labs/assignments were extremely time consuming. Dr. Gayler is an incredible teacher though and he even puts his class lectures online incase you cannot make it to class. I definately advise taking his class, but be prepared to work hard.

Tough class... but Dr Gayler is a great teacher. He will explain it until you understand. He concentrates on theory..so if you have problems generating code then you MUST seek his help. If you are active in class and seek his help he takes that into consideration for your grade!

Very challenging, interesting course. Professor made it make more sense than it did on paper. Lots of difficult assignment, but it's awesome once it clicks and you see how the patterns apply. Very helpful for going into real world situations!

Really great professor, probably the best in the entire CS program. Straight-forward, tests are essay format, and the assignments are challenging yet interesting. The mix of theory with application using RSA was perfect.

Very nice guy, and he hates UGA.  He is always willing to help you no matter what, and does so by barely giving you enough push to get the next step; therefore, he is a professor that helps by helping students figure it out on their own.  If you are willing to work and ask question then he is good for you.

Dr. Gayler uses every bit of class time to explains concepts, and really tries to make sure students understand them -- even going back to explain stuff over again when he sees blank stares in the room. He's usually very available online if you need help, and doesn't mind staying after class to talk.

Only an average professor. He will try to keep you interested and help you learn the concepts of programming but he solely relies on lectures which arent very effective. (they were boring) Compared to my C++ class in Miami I learned very little from him. If you have no other choice take him, it wont be bad but it wont be great

Amazing teacher. Goes above and beyond as far as helping and assisting the student in understanding the concepts. Extra Credit was assigned after the second exam. Said EC, was the sole concept and what the final consisted of entirely! Good guy, corny nerd humor but what's to expect from we CS nerds? Trekky.

RECOMMENDED! During his summer course, he issued test addendums to help if you did not do well on a test. He is fair in grading  and goes over everything to make sure you understand. He is funny and relates well to his students. TAKE THIS CLASS! He is a great guy and a great teacher! Easy A.
Dr. Gayler is not as easy as everyone says, however he is an excellent teacher and he explains the concepts so that you can pass the tests.  Very good, not easy, professor take him!!!!!!!!

Dr. Gayler has a great system for assigning and grading homework.  He is funny and relates to his students very well.  His relationship with his students also supports a very active and involved classroom environment.

Everyone should get full credit on homework, allows for multiple submissions until 100 percent correct.   Plan on reading the text thouroughly, don't just study your notes from class.  Nice guy, willing to help.

Was very helpful.  And I don't think his tests are hard.  As long as you pay attention to what he is saying you will get a good great.  Very easy on you if you are having some problems.  Always ready to help.  Hates UGA, so if you are a big fan of school, don't take him.

One of the worst csis teacher i`ve had...doesn`t give enough support material and his projects are way out of the course scope. Test are very hard and don`t expect to learn much out of this class unless you read the book!
